sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Malaysia is a Southeast Asian country known for its cultural diversity, modern cities, tropical rainforests, and long coastlines. It is split into two main regions: Peninsular Malaysia and East Malaysia on the island of Borneo.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Kuala Lumpur is the capital city of Malaysia and its main economic and cultural center. Putrajaya serves as the federal administrative capital.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency of Malaysia is the Malaysian ringgit (MYR).

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The official language is Malay (Bahasa Malaysia). English, Chinese, and Tamil are also widely spoken.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Malaysian cuisine is influenced by Malay, Chinese, and Indian cultures, with famous dishes such as nasi lemak, satay, laksa, and roti canai.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: Malaysia features tropical rainforests, mountains, rivers, and coastal plains. It is one of the world’s most biodiverse countries.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Malaysian culture emphasizes harmony among different ethnic groups, respect for traditions, and celebration of festivals such as Hari Raya, Chinese New Year, and Deepavali.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Popular tourist destinations include the Petronas Twin Towers, Langkawi Island, Mount Kinabalu, Penang, and historic Malacca.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: Malaysia is home to one of the world’s tallest twin towers—the Petronas Twin Towers.

history.event: Early Malay kingdoms emerged, influenced by Indian trade and culture.
The Malacca Sultanate was founded, becoming a major regional trading power.
Malacca was captured by the Portuguese, beginning European colonial influence.
British control expanded through the Straits Settlements.
Malaya gained independence from British rule.
Malaysia was formed with the inclusion of Sabah and Sarawak.
